item.title: Xbox Goes No-Margin on Its Wireless Gaming Controller, Elite Series 2 Core Drops to an All-Time Low to Compete With Playstation
item.content:encoded:
Need an additional Xbox controller? It’s always a good idea to have an extra in case you want to play with a friend or have one on reserve if you run out of battery. We’ve found one that you can grab right now for a great price, this close to the holidays.

The Xbox Elite Series 2 Core Wireless Gaming Controller is built for players who want more control, comfort, and customization from their gaming sessions. It feels great in your hands, with textured grips and a balanced design that helps you stay comfortable even during long play sessions. No matter what kind of games you like to play, you’ll find this model comfortable and easy to get used to.

See at Amazon

A hardcore Xbox controller that’ll soon become your main

You can get the Xbox Elite Series 2 Core Wireless Gaming Controller right now for just $110, down from its usual price of $150. That is a discount of $40 and 27% off. This is a top of the line controller for the Xbox, so you’re getting a pretty decent price here, considering you’ll usually pay nearly $50 more.

Right out of the box the Elite Series 2 Core feels like an upgrade from a standard controller. The thumbsticks are responsive, the buttons click with just the right amount of feedback, and the overall feel is one of quality. It connects wirelessly to your Xbox or Windows PC, so you can enjoy gaming without cords getting in your way. The Bluetooth support also means you can pair it with other compatible devices for more flexibility.

One of the biggest benefits of this controller is how customizable it is. You can change stick sensitivity, remap buttons, and fine tune settings to match your personal play style. Normally, core Xbox controllers aren’t so easy or versatile when it comes to personalization, so you get a lot more options here to work with. That’s especially useful if you like to change things for shooters or even fighting games to better fit the way you play.

The Elite Series 2 Core also includes additional components you can swap in and out. Different thumbsticks and paddle options let you tweak the feel and response of the controller, so you can tailor it to different genres.

With a solid mix of premium build quality, customization options, and wireless convenience, the Xbox Elite Series 2 Core Wireless Gaming Controller stands out among controllers in its class. For this price, you should go ahead and snatch one up before they raise in price again. Everything gaming-related seems to be getting a price hike, after all.

item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS4
  • PS5
  • Switch
  • Switch 2

Carry over your save data to the full game when it launches.

“Story” and “Battle” demos for The Legend of Heroes: Trails beyond the Horizon, publisher NIS America announced.

The “Story” demo, which features an introduction through the game’s prologue, is available for PlayStation 5, Switch 2, PlayStation 4, Switch, and PC via Steam. The “Battle” demo, which is packed with combat, is available for PlayStation 5 and PlayStation 4.

Here is an overview of each demo, via NIS America:

Story Demo

Play through the Prologue of The Legend of Heroes: Trails beyond the Horizon! Van Arkride and Arkride Solutions return as the fate of the entire Zemurian continent hangs in the balance. With Zemuria preparing for its first space venture, Van Arkride, Rean Schwarzer, and Father Kevin Graham are called to a Marduk training exercise that sets them on a collision course with the secrets at the heart of the world. Their paths may diverge, but the ultimate question remains the same: Just what lies beyond the edge of the horizon?

The Story Demo is available now on PC, Nintendo Switch*, Nintendo Switch 2*, PlayStation 4, and PlayStation 5.

*All save data will carry over to the main game upon release with the day one patch.

Battle Demo

Battle in the Grim Garten! Choose from three party selections (Van, Kevin, and Rean) and take on the Grim Garten, a virtual reality service originally developed by Marduk that has since been hacked by Ouroboros, who altered both its appearance and functionalities. Its earlier version, the ‘Marchen Garten,’ was considered the world’s first fully immersive virtual reality service and had the ability to connect users across the continent through the power of the orbal network.

The Battle Demo is exclusively available now on PlayStation 4 and PlayStation 5.

The Legend of Heroes: Trails beyond the Horizon is due out for PlayStation 5, Switch 2, PlayStation 4, Switch, and PC via Steam, Epic Games Store, and GOG on January 15, 2026 in the west. It first launched for PlayStation 5 and PlayStation 4 on September 26, 2024 in Japan and Asia, followed by PC via Steam on January 23, 2025 in Asia.

item.title: Larian announce plans to let folks ask anything about their generative AI use, asserting "a lot has become lost in translation"
item.content:encoded:
"It would be irresponsible for us not to evaluate new technologies," CEO Swen Vincke adds

Larian hope to offer "more insight" into their usage of generative AI via an ask me anything session set to take place in the new year. It'll also be a chance to ask more general questions about Divinity, if you fancy. Naturally, this all comes after the Geoff announcement of the Baldur's Gate 3 devs' next RPG was swiftly followed by comments from CEO Swen Vincke which revealed the studio are making limited use of generative AI.

In a second response to backlash against his assertions regarding Larian's use of genAI "to explore ideas, flesh out PowerPoint presentations, develop concept art and write placeholder text" - you can get the full context in our other recent pieces - the CEO's announced that the studio'll be hosting an ask me anything chat in the new year. Arguing that "a lot has become lost in translation" following Divinity's announcement, Vincke wrote that this back-and-forth is aimed at offering "the opportunity to ask us any questions you have about Divinity and our dev process directly".

While he put a pin in revealing a concrete date for the chat for now, writing that one'll be forthcoming once the calendar flips over to 2026, the CEO did take this opportunity to offer a bit more of his view on the subject "Larian’s DNA is agency," he wrote. "Everything we work towards is to the benefit of our teams, games, and players. A better work day, and a better game. Our successes come from empowering people to work in their own way and bring the best out of their skill & craft, so that we can make the best RPGs we can possibly make.

It’s been a week since we announced Divinity, our next RPG, and a lot has become lost in translation.

Larian’s DNA is agency. Everything we work towards is to the benefit of our teams, games, and players. A better work day, and a better game. Our successes come from empowering…

— Swen Vincke @where? (@LarAtLarian) December 18, 2025

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

"In that context, it would be irresponsible for us not to evaluate new technologies. However, our processes are always evolving, and where they are not efficient or fail to align with who we are, we will make changes."

To be fair to Vincke and co, you can't accuse them of simply burying their heads and going quiet as the backlash has swirled. The CEO's tried to offer explanations and clarifications in a number of formats, as has Larian's publishing director Michael Douse. I'm not sure the latter's retweeting of posts from YouTubers coming to Larian's defense or attempt to meme up the situation have really helped, but hey, if you reap the rewards of being an abundantly active tweeterperson, you're usually doomed to fall on that same sword at some point.

If you want what I assume to be a meme-free discussion about Divinity itself, you can check out Edwin's chat with Vincke from earlier this week. Or, you can read James' view on the CEO's bit of RAM shortage chat from another stop on the same tour around the publications.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/larian-announce-plans-to-let-folks-ask-anything-about-their-generative-ai-use-asserting-a-lot-has-become-lost-in-translation

item.title: The 15 Best Christmas Songs Ever
item.content:encoded:
Happy holidays and Merry Christmas. This is the time of the year when radio stations start playing holiday-themed music nonstop and commercials are filled with festive tunes. But not all Christmas music is good. In fact, I’d say at least 80 percent of holiday jingles are old, boring, and terrible.

However, I won’t toss all Christmas music under the bus; some holiday tunes have a way of making you feel the warmth and merriment of the season. With that in mind, here are the 15 best tracks to play this year if you want to get into the festive spirit but don’t want to listen to boring old crap. Christmastime is a fun time of year, when people should be feeling good and enjoying time off and the company of loved ones. Or at least getting cool presents. Why ruin that with some slow, sad song from the 1930s?

So here are some good, fun tracks that range from newer hits to oldies that won’t make you fall asleep. And if you work in retail, I am so sorry that you have to spend, like, five weeks listening to all of these and more over and over again, and you all deserve huge bonuses for that torture.

Oh and let us know what your favorite Christmas songs are in the comments below. I’ll be waiting for someone to share Grandma Got Ran Over by a Reindeer. 

Father Christmas – The Kinks

Santa Claus Is Comin’ To Town – Bruce Springsteen

Linus And Lucy – Vince Guaraldi

Last Christmas – Wham!

Run, Rudolph, Run! – Chuck Berry

Feliz Navidad – José Feliciano

All I Want For Christmas Is You – Mariah Carey

Christmas Wrapping – The Waitresses

Christmas (Baby Please Come Home!) – Darlene Love

You’re a Mean One, Mr. Grinch – Thurl Ravenscroft

Holly Jolly Christmas – Burl Ives

Santa Baby – Eartha Kitt

Rockin’ Around The Christmas Tree – Brenda Lee

Underneath The Tree – Kelly Clarkson

I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus – The Jackson 5

item.title: Top Fortnite Players Can Now Get a Free GPU for Playing Fortnite
item.content:encoded:
NVIDIA is offering a free GPU to the best Fortnite players in the world during an upcoming tournament in the game, amid the growing shortage of the gear.

The price of GPU and RAM has skyrocketed in recent months amid growing shortages, driven by the increased use of AI, pricing many out of the components. However, the door has been opened for a limited number of players to claim an NVIDIA GPU in Fortnite.

NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 GPU Available in Fortnite Tournament

On December 21 and 22nd, with the precise date depending on your region, Fortnite is hosting the NVIDIA GeForce RTX Cup, a solo tournament where players can face off to secure grand prizes, including an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 GPU for the “top competitors.”

While earning the GPU requires being one of the best Fortnite players in your region, the shortage and growing price of components makes playing in the Fortnite tournament potentially an easier option than splashing out on the market.

The NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 GPU starts at $999.99 on the NVIDIA website, with prices on the secondary market being even higher.

Participation in the tournament also opens the door to earning a rare cosmetic that has not been available in Fortnite for seven years, the Rust Bucket Back Bling, which will be distributed to all players who earn at least eight points during the tournament.

There are restrictions to competing, however, as players need to have participated in at least 14 tournaments in the past 180 days to be eligible.

What are your thoughts on the rising prices of GPU components? Share your thoughts on the Insider Gaming Discord.
